fields.label_text:
[INTRODUCTORY PANEL]

Other Sides of Bill Brandt
24 March – 25 July 2004

This display is part of the V&A’s centenary celebration of the work of the great British photographer Bill Brandt (1904–83). 

Although Brandt’s work was centred on Britain, he was from a highly cosmopolitan background. He was born in Hamburg, of an English-born father and German mother, and spent part of his youth in a sanatorium in Switzerland, under treatment for tuberculosis. In 1927-8 he underwent psychoanalysis, for the same illness, in Vienna. Here he assisted in a portrait studio and began his photographic career. He also met Eva Boros, who was to become his first wife. In 1930 he worked for Man Ray in Paris. He and Eva travelled together to Hungary, Hamburg, Paris, Madrid and Barcelona before settling in London in 1934. 

Eva compiled two albums, chronicling her life with Bill Brandt, his brother Rolf and their close friends. They contain over 400 photographs (gelatin-silver prints), mostly by Brandt, and are assembled somewhat in the style of the new, illustrated photo-magazines of the time. Twelve pages are shown here. Together they illuminate Bill Brandt’s biography and his development as a photographer. In them we see Brandt trying out different photographic ideas and subjects. Some of the photographs were subsequently published in Brandt’s books and have become classics.

fields.descriptive_line: Album of photographs by Bill Brandt (album consisting of a pale grass weave covered album with dark grey buffed paper pages).
fields.physical_description: The album consists of a pale grass weave covered album with dark grey buffed paper pages.
fields.dimensions: Height: 19 cm album cover, Width: 27.5 cm album cover, Thickness: 3.5 cm album when closed
fields.title: Album of photographs by Bill Brandt

fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level H, case X, shelf 911, box Z  II
Prints & Drawings Study Room, level H

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level H

fields.public_access_description: This album belonged to Bill Brandt's first wife, Eva Boros.  It illustrates Brandt's early photographic career in Vienna, Hungary, Hamburg, Paris, Barcelona, Madrid and London.  In addition to being of primary importance to Brandt's biography, the album illustrates many of the major themes of his oeuvre, such as night life in the St. Paul's district of Hamburg, everyday scenes in Paris and, most importantly, the subject matter of his first two books, 'The English at Home' (1936) and 'A Night in London' (1938).  Many key works are included here in what must be their earliest versions, as relatively small prints (often contact prints).  In addition, these are illuminating photographs that have so far not been published, such as a view of Brandt's bedroom in Paris in 1933, which includes the Surrealist journal 'Varietes'.
fields.exhibition_history: Other Sides of Bill Brandt (Victoria and Albert Museum 01/01/2003-25/07/2004)
fields.bibliography: Paul Dellany, Bill Brandt: A Life, Jonathan Cape, 2004
fields.history_note: The album was purchased by the V&A in 2003, with money from the Sir Cecil Beaton Fund and donations given in memory of Elizabeth Martin, Senior Conservator of Photographs at the V&A from 1981 to 2003.
fields.production_note: This album was compiled by Eva Boros, Bill Brandt's first wife.  The inscriptions found in the album were made by Eva Boros
fields.historical_context_note: This album was bequeathed to Frances Rice by Eva Boros.  The album was purcahsed by the V&A from Frances Rice.
